stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on developing the paper-craft level (Course 14). He refined the spin jump mechanic, brainstormed ideas for placing Yoshi Coins by adding new 'doodle' NPCs, and spent a significant amount of time designing, modeling, and texturing a new 'Thimble Shy Guy' enemy to fit the world's aesthetic.

development_findings.summary: The spin jump was intentionally nerfed to be less powerful for climbing, turning it into more of an aerial stall for recovering from mistakes rather than a primary movement option.
development_findings.quote: I think the spin jump is cool, but it's way too strong. I think it's kind of nice that the impact of each individual A button is more emphasized.

development_findings.summary: Due to a lack of NPCs in the craft level, Kaze is brainstorming creative environmental interactions and new 'doodle' characters (like Shy Guys and Peach) to serve as objectives for the Yoshi Coins.
development_findings.quote: The problem is this level doesn't have many NPCs that we can program interactions with. So we need to be creative and come up with things.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has a clear design philosophy for enemies in the craft world; they must be made of craft materials, not the tools used to make them, leading to the rejection of a scissor enemy.
development_findings.quote: A scissor enemy is lame. Scissor enemies don't fit. There should be a different enemy made out of craft stuff. Probably a scissor enemy is that a scissor is not a craft stuff. It's a tool.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has developed a custom lighting effect for reflective surfaces that calculates light bounce into the camera based on normals, a bespoke solution for the N64 that he struggles to name but understands how to program.
development_findings.quote: You see how when I turn the camera, the brightness of the pixel changes. And it's trying to change so that when the light angle in matches the light angle out, it is the brightest. The idea is that this is kind of like reflective.

development_findings.summary: The unoptimized craft level, with 7,500 triangles (excluding text), runs surprisingly well on actual N64 hardware, validating the current design direction's performance viability.
development_findings.quote: This is the 8000 polygon level that we did not optimize yet. Oh, the grass normal mode works. That's good. I thought this was going to run a lot worse.

development_findings.summary: The blocky, brightly-colored aesthetic of the craft level is an intentional choice designed to reinforce the theme of being made from simple, cut-out materials like cardboard.
development_findings.quote: I think it has to look blocky for the effect to work. And it has to have pretty bright colors.

development_findings.summary: A realization during the stream led to the decision that Shy Guys are an essential enemy for a level themed after Yoshi's Island, prompting a lengthy design session to create a craft-themed version.
development_findings.quote: Now that I think about this, this is Yoshi's Island. We need Shy Guys.

development_findings.summary: Kaze explicitly rejects making design changes that cater specifically to speedrunning exploits, prioritizing the intended player experience.
development_findings.quote: I don't want to do that. I'm not making changes specifically just so you can back amuse.

context_findings.summary: Kaze states he will not charge for the game because he isn't allowed to, but speculates on a free-to-play with paid cosmetics model if he could.
context_findings.quote: If I was allowed to, maybe I would. Actually, what would I do if I was allowed to charge for this game? Probably release the base game for free and then you could buy a skin or something.

context_findings.summary: Kaze has noticed a specific, consistent negative response to his videos, which he finds more amusing and exciting than discouraging.
context_findings.quote: I have also taken notes that I think we have our first real hater, which is news for me. There's one person disliking every video I upload like two minutes after I upload it. So this is exciting.

context_findings.summary: Kaze asserts that while he appreciates speedrunning techniques, he will not specifically design or alter mechanics to cater to that playstyle, prioritizing his core design vision.
context_findings.quote: I'm not making changes specifically just so you can back amuse. If you can back amuse, that's a great. I enjoyed it as well, but I'm not going to cater to that.

context_findings.summary: The project has a strict design rule to only include characters, elements, and concepts that existed in the N64 era (pre-2001) or are original creations, maintaining a period-appropriate feel.
context_findings.quote: We're not referencing anything Nintendo made up for like 1996 or after 2001, whenever the last N64 game released. We're also not adding anything that was invented after Nintendo 64 unless we invented it ourselves, basically.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges the need to step away from an asset he's been working on intensely to regain a fresh perspective, showing self-awareness in his creative process.
context_findings.quote: I don't know, maybe I just have to get back to this in a week or so. Because right now I'm so used to this that it doesn't look weird to me. Maybe I just need to give it a break, you know what I mean?

biobak.summary: Biobak was responsible for removing post-N64 era enemy images from a texture to align with the project's design constraints.
biobak.quote: I'm pretty sure we swapped those out. Because I know exactly what you're talking about and I know I don't want that. And I'm pretty sure Biobak swapped those out. Yeah, look, they're gone.

biobak.summary: Kaze mentions that Biobak is almost finished with a 'dummy', though the nature of this asset is not specified.

badub.summary: Kaze is waiting for Badub's music for the craft level and hopes it will be dynamic, changing based on the player's location within the level's different biomes.
badub.quote: I'm gonna see what music Badub is gonna come up. Ideally I'm gonna have a music that changes depending on which biome of the level you're in.

zeina.summary: Zeina is planning to create hand-drawn cloud assets for the level, influencing Kaze's decision not to spend too much time on the current placeholder clouds.
zeina.quote: Zeina wants to draw in clouds anyway, so I'm attaching them right now.

zeina.summary: When asked about something labeled '13', Kaze mentions that Zeina is currently working on it.

key_stories.title: Nerfing the Spin Jump
key_stories.summary: Kaze identified the spin jump as an overpowered mechanic that broke level design. He systematically nerfed its height and speed, transforming it from a powerful climbing tool into a defensive aerial stall meant to give players a chance to recover from mistakes.
key_stories.challenge: The existing spin jump was too powerful, allowing players to easily climb vertical surfaces and undermining the intended platforming challenges.
key_stories.process: Kaze identified the spin jump as 'oppressive' to the game's design. He experimented with its properties, reducing initial velocity, decreasing horizontal movement, and tweaking the height gained from button mashes until it felt right.
key_stories.outcome: The spin jump was rebalanced into an aerial stall mechanic. It no longer provides significant height but offers a moment of airtime to correct jumps, making it a defensive security tool rather than an offensive movement option.
key_stories.key_quote: I want this to be a very slow thing, that you kind of like do not want to use, but that gives you a feeling of security when it's available to you.

key_stories.title: Designing the Thimble Shy Guy
key_stories.summary: To populate the craft level, Kaze needed a new enemy that fit the theme. He settled on a 'Thimble Shy Guy' and spent a significant portion of the stream modeling it and programming a custom, multi-layered texture to give it a convincing metallic and bumpy look on the N64.
key_stories.challenge: The arts-and-crafts themed level needed a thematically appropriate enemy, but initial ideas like a scissor monster were rejected for not fitting the 'made of crafts' rule.
key_stories.process: After rejecting a 'tool' enemy, Kaze brainstormed craft-based creatures, landing on the idea of a Shy Guy made from a thimble. This led to a lengthy process of 3D modeling, texture painting, and complex technical work to create a convincing, period-appropriate metallic sheen.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully designed and modeled a 'Thimble Shy Guy'. He created a custom metallic, bumpy texture using multi-texturing techniques to simulate a specular shine on N64 hardware, creating an enemy that fits the world's aesthetic.
key_stories.key_quote: What if we use one of those with like eyes drawn on? That would be perfect for a Shy Guy.

key_stories.title: Populating the Craft World
key_stories.summary: Faced with an empty level and no clear way to implement Yoshi Coin objectives, Kaze pivoted from complex environmental ideas to populating the world with new 'doodle' NPCs. This led to creating a 'rescue Peach from Shy Guys' mission, solving the content problem.
key_stories.challenge: The craft level felt empty and lacked the NPC-driven objectives needed to place the five Yoshi Coins in an engaging way.
key_stories.process: Kaze first considered environmental puzzles like a waterfall, but rejected them due to interaction complexity. Realizing the level's connection to Yoshi's Island, he decided to add doodle versions of classic characters, which naturally created opportunities for small missions and secrets.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze developed a plan to add multiple 'paper doodle' NPCs, including a Peach who needs rescuing from the new Thimble Shy Guys, a paper Bowser guarding an area, and potentially pink Bob-ombs. This populates the world and provides clear objectives for Yoshi Coins.
key_stories.key_quote: The problem is this level doesn't have many NPCs that we can program interactions with. So we need to be creative and come up with things.
